Title: Amygdalofugal and amygdalopetal connections with modality-specific visual cortical areas in macaques (Macaca fuscata, M. mulatta, M. fascicularis)
Abstract: The origins and terminations of the amygdaloid connections with the modality-specific visual cortical areas TEa (anterior TE area), TEp (posterior TE area), TEO, V4, V2, MST (medial superior temporal visual area), MT (middle temporal visual area), and V1 were studied in macaques. These were compared with the amygdaloid connections of a vision-related polysensory area TG by making cortical injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and incubating the sections with tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as the chromogen. Both areas TEa and TEp receive a major projection from the lateral basal nucleus and a minor one from the accessory basal nucleus of the amygdaloid complex, whereas these areas send a major projection to the lateral nucleus and a minor one to the lateral basal nucleus. Areas TEO, V4, V2, MST, MT, and V1 receive projections only from the lateral basal nucleus; none of them project to any amygdaloid nucleus. Thus, the amygdalofugal projections are more widespread and more complex than the amygdalopetal projections. These findings indicate that the connections between the amygdaloid nuclei and the visual areas are generally nonreciprocal and underlie the importance of a feedback mechanism from the amygdala to the visual cortical areas in visual information processing. There appears to be a caudorostral (occipitotemporal) gradient in the distribution and density of the amygdaloid projections, which become progressively more widespread and heavier among the progressively more rostral visual areas (from area V1 to area TEa). The amygdaloid connections with area TG are distinctly different from the connections with the visual areas. Area TG is reciprocally connected mainly with the periamygdaloid cortex, and with the lateral, accessory basal, and medial basal nuclei of the amygdala as well.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "In this study, 3 different species of macaques were employed. Because the amygdaloid complex showed little cytoarchitectonic variation across these species, the nuclear classification of Crosby and Humphrey ('41) with modifications derived from Price ('81a) and Amaral and Price ('84) was adopted for this study. The cytoarchitectonic characteristics of the individual amygdaloid nuclei have been described elsewhere (Johnston, '23; Crosby and Humphrey, '41; Lauer, '45; Jimenez-Castellanos, '49; Koikegami, '63; Kusama and Mabuchi, '70; Turner et al., '80; Aggleton and Mishkin, '84). The present study confirmed these previous findings, which are not described here. ...The lateral basal and medial basal nuclei are respectively the magnocellular and parvicellular subdivisions of the basal (B) nucleus of Crosby and Hunphrey ('41; see also Lauer, '45; Price, '81a). ...The periamygdaloid cortex itself was not homogeneous in cytoarchitecture; the caudal part is a transition zone (crtical transition area; Aggleton and Mishkin, '84; Aggleton, '85) with both the medial basal and accessory basal nuclei, which lie deep to it, and the entorhinal cortex, which is immediately ventral. Following the classification of Price ('81a) and Amaral and Price ('84)., however, the cortical transition area was not separated from the periamygdaloid cortex proper." (pp. 365-366)

Following the classification of Price ('81a) and Amaral and Price ('84)., however, the cortical transition area was not separated from the periamygdaloid cortex proper." (pp. 365-366)

"The medial superior temporal visual area (area MST, Maunsell and Van Essen, '83) is located deep on the anterior bank of the dorsocaudal superior temporal sulcus (see Fig. 12A), and thus belongs cytoarchitectonically to area PG (von Bonin and Bailey, '47), which has been considered to be a polysensory area (Jones and Powell, '70)." (p. 365)

"The medial superior temporal visual area (area MST, Maunsell and Van Essen, '83) is located deep on the anterior bank of the dorsocaudal superior temporal sulcus (see Fig. 12A), and thus belongs cytoarchitectonically to area PG (von Bonin and Bailey, '47), which has been considered to be a polysensory area (Jones and Powell, '70)." (p. 365)

"The delineations of areas TG, TEa, TEp, and TEO were based essentially on the cytoarchitectonic charts of von Bonin and Bailey ('47), and those of areas V4, V2, MST, MT, and V1, on the physiological maps of Gattass et al. ('85), Tanaka et al. ('86), Saito et al. ('86), and Daniel and Whitteridge ('61), with reference to the functional and myeloarchitectonic findings in our laboratory (Iwai, '82)." (p. 364)

We therefore, investigated these subdivisions separately; the border between them was established as a vertical line at the posterior tip of the anterior middle temporal sulcus. It should be noted here that our area TEa is different from the area TEa of Seltzer and Pandya ('78)." (p. 364)

"Recent studies have demonstrated that prestriate cortex (areas OA and OB) consists of several subdivisions, including areas V2, V3, V3A, V4, MT, and PO. In this study, areas V4 (Van Essen and Zeki, '78; Gattass et al., '85), V2 (Zeki and Sandeman, '76; Gattass et al., '81), and MT (middle temporal visual area, Zeki, '74; Ungerleider and Mishkin, '79; Gattass and Gross, '81; Van Essen et al., '81) were investigated." (p. 365)

"Recent studies have demonstrated that prestriate cortex (areas OA and OB) consists of several subdivisions, including areas V2, V3, V3A, V4, MT, and PO. In this study, areas V4 (Van Essen and Zeki, '78; Gattass et al., '85), V2 (Zeki and Sandeman, '76; Gattass et al., '81), and MT (middle temporal visual area, Zeki, '74; Ungerleider and Mishkin, '79; Gattass and Gross, '81; Van Essen et al., '81) were investigated." (p. 365)

"Area V4 is strip zone extending dorsoventrally. Dorsally, it occupies the preoccipital gyrus, extending to the anterior bank of the lunate sulcus and the posterior bank of the superior temporal sulcus. Ventromedially, it occupies the inferior occipital gyrus and the lateral part of the lingular gyrus, including both banks of the inferior occipital, occipitotemporal, and collateral sulci (Gattass et al., '85). Although Van Essen ('85) calls this ventral region area VA/V4 and considers it separate from area V4, in the present study this region is considered to be part of V4 (Gattass et al., '85; Ungerleider, '85)." (p. 365)

(p. 365)

The cytoarchitectonic characteristics of the individual amygdaloid nuclei have been described elsewhere (Johnston, '23; Crosby and Humphrey, '41; Lauer, '45; Jimenez-Castellanos, '49; Koikegami, '63; Kusama and Mabuchi, '70; Turner et al., '80; Aggleton and Mishkin, '84). The present study confirmed these previous findings, which are not described here. ...The lateral basal and medial basal nuclei are respectively the magnocellular and parvicellular subdivisions of the basal (B) nucleus of Crosby and Hunphrey ('41; see also Lauer, '45; Price, '81a). ...The periamygdaloid cortex itself was not homogeneous in cytoarchitecture; the caudal part is a transition zone (crtical transition area; Aggleton and Mishkin, '84; Aggleton, '85) with both the medial basal and accessory basal nuclei, which lie deep to it, and the entorhinal cortex, which is immediately ventral. Following the classification of Price ('81a) and Amaral and Price ('84)., however, the cortical transition area was not separated from the periamygdaloid cortex proper." (pp. 365-366)

"The medial superior temporal visual area (area MST, Maunsell and Van Essen, '83) is located deep on the anterior bank of the dorsocaudal superior temporal sulcus (see Fig. 12A), and thus belongs cytoarchitectonically to area PG (von Bonin and Bailey, '47), which has been considered to be a polysensory area (Jones and Powell, '70)." (p. 365)

"The medial superior temporal visual area (area MST, Maunsell and Van Essen, '83) is located deep on the anterior bank of the dorsocaudal superior temporal sulcus (see Fig. 12A), and thus belongs cytoarchitectonically to area PG (von Bonin and Bailey, '47), which has been considered to be a polysensory area (Jones and Powell, '70)." (p. 365)

"The delineations of areas TG, TEa, TEp, and TEO were based essentially on the cytoarchitectonic charts of von Bonin and Bailey ('47), and those of areas V4, V2, MST, MT, and V1, on the physiological maps of Gattass et al. ('85), Tanaka et al. ('86), Saito et al. ('86), and Daniel and Whitteridge ('61), with reference to the functional and myeloarchitectonic findings in our laboratory (Iwai, '82)." (p. 364)

(p. 364) "Turner et al. ('80) have divided area TE into 2 subdivisions; an anterior TE (area TEa) and a posterior TE (arae TEp). We therefore, investigated these subdivisions separately; the border between them was established as a vertical line at the posterior tip of the anterior middle temporal sulcus. It should be noted here that our area TEa is different from the area TEa of Seltzer and Pandya ('78)." (p. 364)

We therefore, investigated these subdivisions separately; the border between them was established as a vertical line at the posterior tip of the anterior middle temporal sulcus. It should be noted here that our area TEa is different from the area TEa of Seltzer and Pandya ('78)." (p. 364)

"The delineations of areas TG, TEa, TEp, and TEO were based essentially on the cytoarchitectonic charts of von Bonin and Bailey ('47), and those of areas V4, V2, MST, MT, and V1, on the physiological maps of Gattass et al. ('85), Tanaka et al. ('86), Saito et al. ('86), and Daniel and Whitteridge ('61), with reference to the functional and myeloarchitectonic findings in our laboratory (Iwai, '82)." (p. 364) "Turner et al. ('80) have divided area TE into 2 subdivisions; an anterior TE (area TEa) and a posterior TE (arae TEp). We therefore, investigated these subdivisions separately; the border between them was established as a vertical line at the posterior tip of the anterior middle temporal sulcus. It should be noted here that our area TEa is different from the area TEa of Seltzer and Pandya ('78)." (p. 364)

"Recent studies have demonstrated that prestriate cortex (areas OA and OB) consists of several subdivisions, including areas V2, V3, V3A, V4, MT, and PO. In this study, areas V4 (Van Essen and Zeki, '78; Gattass et al., '85), V2 (Zeki and Sandeman, '76; Gattass et al., '81), and MT (middle temporal visual area, Zeki, '74; Ungerleider and Mishkin, '79; Gattass and Gross, '81; Van Essen et al., '81) were investigated." (p. 365)

"Recent studies have demonstrated that prestriate cortex (areas OA and OB) consists of several subdivisions, including areas V2, V3, V3A, V4, MT, and PO. (p. 365)

"Area V4 is strip zone extending dorsoventrally. Dorsally, it occupies the preoccipital gyrus, extending to the anterior bank of the lunate sulcus and the posterior bank of the superior temporal sulcus. Ventromedially, it occupies the inferior occipital gyrus and the lateral part of the lingular gyrus, including both banks of the inferior occipital, occipitotemporal, and collateral sulci (Gattass et al., '85). Although Van Essen ('85) calls this ventral region area VA/V4 and considers it separate from area V4, in the present study this region is considered to be part of V4 (Gattass et al., '85; Ungerleider, '85)." (p. 365)

In case 10, 0.04 microliter of HRP was injected into the ventral portion of the prelunate gyrus, and the injection site was well localized in that part of area V4 (Fig. 3B) which, according to the studies of Gattass et al. ('85) and Yukie and Iwai ('85), represents 2-10 degree in the lower visual field. In case 11, 0.03 microliter of HRP was injected into the dorsal portion of the prelunate gyrus, and the injection site was located in the representation of the lower 20-40 degree in area V4. In case 12, an injection of 0.6 microliter of HRP was made into the lateral part of the inferior occipital gyrus, which represents the upper central 15 degree in area V4, but the injection site also extended well into area V3 and slightly into the ventral part of area TEO as well. In case 13, an injection of 0.1 microliter of HRP was made into the lateral part of the lingular gyrus, which represents the upper 20-50 degree in area V4, but this injection extended slightly to areas V3 and V2." (pp. 373-374)

"Injections of HRP were made into diferent parts of area V2 in 4 cases (cases 14-17; Fig. 10A). In case 14, an injection of 0.04 microliter of HRP was made into the ventral portion of the posterior bank of the lunate sulcus, which contains the representation of 1-3 degree of the lower visual field. In case 25, an injection of 0.04 microliter of HRP was made into the lip of the upper bank of the inferior occipital sulcus, which contains the representation of 1-3 degree in the upper visual field (Gattass et al., '81; our unpublished data). The injection sites in these 2 cases were well localized in the intended portions of area V2. In cases 16 and 17, injections of 0.05 microliter of HRP were made into the portions of area V2 above and below the calcarine fissure which are respectively the representations of the lower 30-60 degree and the upper 15-30 degree. The injection site in case 16 (Fig. 3C) was well localized in area V2, but the injection site in case 17 extended slightly into area V1." (p. 375)

"We made injections of 0.04-0.05 microliter of HRP within area MT in 3 cases (cases 22-24) and within area MST in 1 (case 25). The injection sites in area MT were located in the fundus and on the deep part of the posterior bank of the superior temporal sulcus (Fig. 12A). The MST injection was localized on the deep part of the anterior bank of the superior temporal sulcus, rostrally adjacent to area MT (Fig. 12A). The localization of injection sites to areas MT and MST was confirmed by myeloarchitectonic criteria (Ungerleider and Mishkin, '79; Van Essen et al., '81; Tanaka, Yukie, Iwai et al., '86)." (p. 379)

publication.title: Amygdalofugal and amygdalopetal connections with modality-specific visual cortical areas in macaques (Macaca fuscata, M. mulatta, M. fascicularis)
publication.abstract: The origins and terminations of the amygdaloid connections with the modality-specific visual cortical areas TEa (anterior TE area), TEp (posterior TE area), TEO, V4, V2, MST (medial superior temporal visual area), MT (middle temporal visual area), and V1 were studied in macaques. These were compared with the amygdaloid connections of a vision-related polysensory area TG by making cortical injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and incubating the sections with tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as the chromogen. Both areas TEa and TEp receive a major projection from the lateral basal nucleus and a minor one from the accessory basal nucleus of the amygdaloid complex, whereas these areas send a major projection to the lateral nucleus and a minor one to the lateral basal nucleus. Areas TEO, V4, V2, MST, MT, and V1 receive projections only from the lateral basal nucleus; none of them project to any amygdaloid nucleus. Thus, the amygdalofugal projections are more widespread and more complex than the amygdalopetal projections. These findings indicate that the connections between the amygdaloid nuclei and the visual areas are generally nonreciprocal and underlie the importance of a feedback mechanism from the amygdala to the visual cortical areas in visual information processing. There appears to be a caudorostral (occipitotemporal) gradient in the distribution and density of the amygdaloid projections, which become progressively more widespread and heavier among the progressively more rostral visual areas (from area V1 to area TEa). The amygdaloid connections with area TG are distinctly different from the connections with the visual areas. Area TG is reciprocally connected mainly with the periamygdaloid cortex, and with the lateral, accessory basal, and medial basal nuclei of the amygdala as well.
